bioghist.p: Herbert M. Hadley (d. 1998) was the son of a Quaker missionary and grew up in Alaska and Kansas. He graduated in 1939 from Friends University in Wichita, Kansas, and then became principal of the North Branch Friends Academy. During World War II, he was a conscientious objector, and served for four years in various units of the Civilian Public Service. After the war, he married Ruthanna Davis. He received his master's degree in American civilization from the University of Pennsylvania. In 1947 he became the secretary of the Friends Meeting in Washington D.C. In 1956, he was appointed executive secretary of the Friends World Committee for Consultation (FWCC), and traveled extensively around the world. In 1962, Hadley returned to the United States and served as the head of the American section of the FWCC. He was a long-time member of Germantown Meeting and was a member of the Friends Historical Association. In 1969 he was elected as a member of the Corporation of Haverford College. In 1991, he published Quakers World Wide: A History of Friends World Committee for Consultation.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Herbert M. Hadley's papers related to the research for and production of his book, Quakers World Wide. Materials include correspondence, biographical sketches of FWCC figures, articles, FWCC newsletters, minutes of the Executive, Interim, and Advisory Committees of the FWCC; records of Hadley's expenses; and documents related to reviews, marketing, and distribution of the book.
